messageBody:
JB responded:

> Jonathan Oddy wrote:
>
>> Does this seem like a resonable direction to be going - or am I setting
>> myself up for an unpleasant (unforseen) fall somewhere later down the
track?
>>
>> Any thoughts/criticisms welcome.
>
> Quick question: what are you trying to test? Deserialization? or using
> the deserialized object? Both?

The later (is that the right answer?) I am trying to test some behaviour
that requires the services of some other class "A", my problem with faking
"A" is that there are (potentially) lots of methods within "A" that I might
like to use within the behaviour under test/implementation. If I go the
fake route (which I do reasonably regularly) then I have to fake *all* of
the methods that I am interested in, granted I can produce a whole host of
factory methods to create these fakes (and have for certain classes and
uses) but in this instance there appears to be a lot of extra work here for
not much gain, especially when there is a real risk that my fake *might*
introduce some assumption that is clearly wrong, or an assumption that was
correct until I changed the actual implementation of "A" for some other fix.
I have already been biten by this (which probably says more about me than it
should...) and spent longer than I wished tracking down the fault in some
production code.

I have a number of deserialisation tests for those classes being
deserialised - so that's not what I am testing here. I am simply using the
fact that I "know" I have a "working" deserialisation process on some class
"A" to speed up my test creation process. It is much easier to data-scrape
an objects serialised form from a log file and use an object constructed
from that within my test than to fake it. At least when using a
deserialised instance, I am using a first class object with no assumptions
hardcoded (other than those within the class itself). I do concede that I
am coding assumptions via the data that the object is being populated from.

> (Do you get the hint in the question?)
Not today, my brain hurts thanks to "young-children-not-sleeping-syndrome".

My gut feeling is, as the other responder suggested, to do both and chose
the appropriate form for the situation currently being worked upon.

Jonathan
